title: Monday, 18th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

Let me go straight to the pic of the day

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Paddy McGuinness, former comic

PM11:02am

Taking the shabby Jackpotjoy shilling

PM11:02am

Jackpotjoy launches new integrated advertising campaign

Paddy McGuinness to be the new face of the brand

11:03 am
BE11:03am

.......... cripes.

PM11:03am

Taking over from Babs Windsor as the draw for a certain type of elderly, compulsive (female) gambler that passes for Jackpotjoy's "customers"

PM11:03am

Nasty

11:03 am
Jackpotjoy PLC (JPJ:LSE): Last: 748.50, up 6 (+0.81%), High: 749.50, Low: 741.00, Volume: 4.15k
PM11:04am

Which institutions actually own this company?

PM11:04am

UBS, Odey

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Actually, not many institutions on the list

BE11:05am

And guessing Odey was a cornerstone investor at the float.

PM11:05am

Assume so

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Good luck to him. I guess. And all shareholders. And Paddy. Especially Paddy.

undefined
PM11:06am

So sterling stopped going up, for the moment

11:06 am
PM11:06am

So stocks a tad firmer

PM11:06am

FTSE 100 up 20 points or so at 7235

BE11:06am

Yes, we seem to have flattened off a bit post the hawkish stuff. FTSE going nowhere in particular.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Ahead 20 points at 7235 right now.

BE11:07am

Though that's no reason to be even slightly positive.

BE11:07am

JP Morgan selling the UK this morning.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Because it doesn't like EM.

PM11:08am

Wot?!?

PM11:08am

It's saying we're an emerging market -- or that the Footsie is heavily EM exposed?

11:08 am
BE11:08am

The latter. They've not yet concluded that the UK is now an emerging market, though I expect you could get good clickbait from making that argument.

BE11:09am

Gist here is that JPM's expecting an EM pullback post a good few months.

BE11:09am

And if you're expecing an EM pullback plus rising bond yields, don't buy the UK.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

BE11:09am

BE11:10am

Let me get the first page to talk you through all the moving parts.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

· At the start of September, we advised to add risk to equities again, post the consolidation witnessed since May, where SXXP fell 7%. Within this, we believe that the two key variables that we tend to look at for most trades, bond yields and FX, will swap places in the order of importance. · Since Q1 we were arguing that the interest rate differential between the US and RoW, which was at a 30-year high, needed to close, one way or other, and that in turn would be bullish for the Euro/bearish for the USD. This call drove our OW on EM vs DM equities, and OW on Miners within sectors.

BE11:10am

· We would still be cautious on the USD over the medium term, JPM expects 1.25 EUR/USD by next Sept, but we believe that USD call will move to the backburner over the next few months. Euro speculative positions are outright long now, at 3 year highs, and USD appears to have undershot the interest rate differential between the US and Europe. Expectations over any US growth policy delivery, as well as Fed hikes projections, are very subdued these days. Some positive surprise is possible on these fronts now.

BE11:10am

· In our view, the driving variable into the end of the year is likely to be the direction of bond yields. In our last week’s report we outlined key reasons why yields were likely to bounce into Q4, from what were very overbought bond levels at the start of September. The likely pickup in inflation prints in Q4, resilient activity – with big gap between PMIs and yields opening up, as well as a potential repricing of central bank policy path, given an overly dovish starting point today, are the supports.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

This is all very logical -- exposure wise

BE11:10am

· Given the above, we think it is prudent to take profits on EM, which are up as much as 28% ytd, and on Miners too, which are up 25% relative in the past 3 months. We move both from OW to N. We see this as only a tactical call, profit taking, rather than as a fundamental change of direction. We believe EM backdrop still looks attractive over the medium term.

BE11:11am

It is. Logical to the point of slightly dull. But I guess it makes a handy script to tell the clients.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

· We are also cutting UK, to UW, given its high EM exposure, and adding to Japan, from UW to N. Japan underperformed global equities ytd, it is looking cheap again and the bulk of the JPY strength might be behind us.

BE11:11am

· Eurozone (OW) is in a very good spot currently, we believe, as it benefits from any rise in bond yields, and the most of the near term damage from stronger Euro is likely already absorbed, especially as it is a fully consensus view now to be bullish on the Euro. Euphoria over Eurozone that was in place since May, in the aftermath of French elections, and which prompted us to take some profits then, appears to have fully unwound. Eurozone is cheaper, and outflows have returned, too. We think this is a good sign.

BE11:11am

Sectorwise, we believe Financials, we are OW both Banks and Insurance, and Cyclicals will lead into year end, while bond proxies will lag. We reiterate our recent double upgrade of Capital Goods, and downgrade of Staples to UW. This year we held OW on domestic basket - JPDEEZDR, vs short exporters - JPDEEZEX, but neutralise this trade following a strong run, and expect both groups to work equally from here.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

There's also a companion note from Fraser Jamieson, the mining analyst, saying "actually! we don't think miners are expensive. But, yes, okay, that all makes sense so fair enough."

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,328, down 2.47 (-0.19%), High: 1,344, Low: 1,327, Volume: 1.55m
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,286, down 4.5 (-0.35%), High: 1,304, Low: 1,283, Volume: 817.71k
11:12 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,459, up 6.5 (+0.19%), High: 3,489, Low: 3,456, Volume: 664.33k
BE11:13am

And that's the excitement of Monday morning strategy covered.

undefined
11:13 am
PM11:13am

This Rentokil chap...

PM11:13am

PM11:13am

Chris Geoghegan

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Forced out after it emerged taht Geoghegan pulled in $100k plus for introducing Bell Pottinger to the Guptas

PM11:14am

Not clever.

PM11:14am

Joe Cotterill (cover the whole Gupta story) is in Maptuo at the moment

11:14 am
PM11:14am

But comments..

PM11:14am

Talk about pest control.

PM11:15am

Short statement here

11:15 am
PM11:15am

https://www.invest...1709180700069657Q/

Rentokil Initial PLC (RTO:LSE): Last: 297.00, up 1.8 (+0.61%), High: 297.40, Low: 295.30, Volume: 742.28k
PM11:15am

Damaged quite a few reputations, this scandal

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Does it have further to run? Maybe. Yes Wink smile

BE11:16am

I think Mr Geoghegan had only just been appointed as Rentokil's Senior Independent Director and chairman of the Remuneration Committee.

BE11:16am

As in, no more than a couple of months ago.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

This is falling on the sword from a great height.

undefined
PM11:17am

It was May -- but yes, broadly right

11:17 am
PM11:17am

GKN -- top of the leader board

PM11:17am

I was struggling to find out why earlier

BE11:17am

Breakup!

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Maybe.

PM11:17am

Then it turns out it was Exane

PM11:17am

Ah, really?

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Well, yes. It's Exane doing the breakup theory.

BE11:18am

Which gained traction somewhat suddenly on Friday, and we mentioned in the paper on Saturday.

BE11:18am

As of today, Exane picks up the torch.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

In a recent note, Europe: Channel Trouble, Exane’s Autos team adopted an increasingly bearish stance regarding the European Auto market, while the US market is already showing signs of slowing down. GKN’s automotive exposure amounts to c.60% of Group revenues; in the context of a deteriorating industry outlook, why upgrade to Neutral now?

BE11:18am

Recent events lead us to believe a break-up of the Group is now more likely

BE11:18am

Back in summer 2016, media reports suggested that Chinese SAIC Motor Corporation could be about to bid for GKN ...

11:18 am
BE11:18am

That was us, incidentally: https://ftalphavil...live/2016-09-05-2/

PM11:18am

Omg smile

BE11:19am

One of those ones where you can't quite understand why there hasn't been a statement. Though of course, statements aren't required once deals die.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Back to Exane.

BE11:19am

In our view, it is unlikely that either the UK or US government would permit GKN Aerospace to fall into Chinese hands. We therefore consider that any move by the Chinese will be limited to GKN’s Automotive assets. Such a disposal would be well timed from an Auto end market perspective, while the Chinese would gain Tier 1 supplier access to Global Auto OEMs. GKN’s recent bond issuance reduced the pension deficit, meaning GKN is now easier to break up. In addition, the announcement of the departure of the CEO and his replacement with the head of GKN Aerospace may be a signal to the market that the future of GKN, post a possible disposal of its Automotive businesses, lies purely within Aerospace. The CFO is leaving too; his replacement is currently head of M&A and Strategy, which in our view, also points to increased potential for portfolio change.

BE11:20am

We move to value Driveline and Powder Metallurgy on a breakup basis

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Our SOTP-based valuation (2018e) now reflects the potential for a disposal of Driveline and Powder Metallurgy. We value both businesses at 11x FY18e EBIT; a 10% premium to its European Automotive supplier peer Group, a choice which we believe allows us to better capture the break-up optionality. We increase our TP to 350p, from 295p. Upgrade to Neutral.

PM11:20am

I do love the way you are able to share Exane research with us Bryce.

BE11:20am

It's not easy!

11:20 am
PM11:20am

You know they'll be going nuts in their office on the top of the Regent St Apple stuff

PM11:20am

nuts

PM11:21am

Exane are one of those brokers who reckon the best way to approach Mifid II is to put all research on lock down

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Clients will have to pay a single platform fee for everything -- or get nothing at all

BE11:22am

Yeah -- in common with several brokers we simply can't get Exane direct any more.

PM11:22am

You can see their point -- Exane is not a big integrated bank, with all sorts of other products that it can cross sell with research

11:22 am
PM11:22am

It's a broker - with a bunch of top rated analysts

BE11:22am

Absolutely. But the problem with Exane research is that it's good and moves markets.

BE11:23am

Our job is to explain why markets move. If we can't tell you about it, that promotes market asymmetry.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

No one wants that, right?

BE11:23am

We're heroes really.

PM11:23am

Creating a two tier market. Bloody regulation -- who does it benefit? Not the little guy, that's for sure

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Sorry, that was rather populist

BE11:23am

I agree, broadly speaking.

BE11:24am

Anyway, we've also got Sandy Morris writing on GKN and he's rather friendlier when if comes to the oxygen of efficient markets or whatever.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Here's his GKN breakup thing from Friday.

BE11:24am

Conclusion: Autoliv’s proposed demerger and yesterday’s management changes appear likely to refresh the debate about whether GKN might also demerge. Finding near peers for GKN Auto and GKN Aero is tricky, the Driveline China JVs may be a stumbling block, and the pension deficit remains a factor, but we can do some simple – if imprecise –arithmetic. Nonetheless, we venture there is value to play with.
Details: For Driveline, we have viewed Autoliv and Borg Warner (BW) as peers. BW’s Bloomberg consensus FY18 PER is 12.1x; Autoliv is now 18x. Our total forecast Driveline + Powder Met FY18 EBIT is £520m which after tax of 24% is EPS of 23p. Assume a PER of 13x = 299p. Our forecast FY18 Aero EBIT is £410m, so EPS of 18p – and if we use Spirit Aero’s FY18 Bberg consensus PER of 14.5x that gives 263p. Total 562p. Actuarial pension deficit after £250m planned payment is @£550m so 32p/share. GKN net debt end FY18 forecast at 26p/share. Total net outcome is 504p.

BE11:25am

Weird that none of the Sunday papers picked up on the theory, incidentally. But that's not my worry.

11:25 am
GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 349.60, up 10.8 (+3.19%), High: 350.80, Low: 341.10, Volume: 3.38m
undefined
PM11:26am

Is this sector wide? ie reason for BAE Systems?

11:25 am
BE11:26am

We've sold some planes!

PM11:26am

Ah

PM11:26am

Don't tell me -- to the middle east

11:26 am
BE11:26am

24 Eurofighters to Qatar.

PM11:26am

How does this fit with the Saudi squabble?

PM11:26am

I thought Saudi were a rather large customer of BAE

11:26 am
PM11:27am

Like, forever

BE11:27am

...................................................... Yeah, Saudi is something like a fifth of group revenue (don't quote me on that, it'll be in Google).

BE11:27am

Anyway, this is a lifeline for the Typhoon programme.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Which underpins estimates for a while.

BE11:28am

Have Goldman to say, "that's good."

BE11:28am

On Sunday September 17 Qatar signed a letter of intent to purchase 24 Typhoon aircraft from BAE Systems. This LOI could translate into an order before year-end, but until contract terms are announced we expect these aircraft would be built in the UK and would begin to contribute to revenue on the Typhoon program from 2019.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Initial delivery of jets may be beyond 2019 but revenue (and cash) is likely to be received and booked based on work done.
This commitment marks one of the largest export successes for BAE Systems in recent years, and follows a deal for 20 jets to Oman in 2012 and 28 jets to Kuwait (signed by Leonardo) in 2016. Given Qatar does not currently operate any Typhoon aircraft, the package is likely to include substantial training and support services. This deal is a slight negative for Dassault Aviation; Dassault has already signed a contract to supply Qatar with 24 Rafale fighters in 2015, in our view this Typhoon LOI significantly reduces the likelihood of a follow on order.

BE11:29am

And Citi.

BE11:30am

In our initiation piece “There’s No Accounting For Cash: Revisiting valuation - Key Buys: Airbus, BAE, Rolls Royce” (page 31) we estimated that the value of Batch 2 to Saudi (48 aircraft) would be about 40p per share, including aftermarket and upgrades – on this basis we estimate that the Qatar deal (assuming it proceeds from a statement of intent to contract) would be worth 20-25p per share (maybe a little higher per aircraft than Batch 2 Saudi as the Saudis already have a fleet of 72 Typhoons, so there would be some benefits of scale and utilization of existing infrastructure).

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Our initial sales estimate is shown in Figure 1 – Using a DCF, we estimate the value of this contract is 20-25p, although this will also help keep the production line open
and may help further export contracts (such as Batch 2 to Saudi).

BE11:30am

You'll be wanting to see figure 1.

BE11:30am

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Told you.

undefined
BE11:31am

Esure mentioned on the right.

11:31 am
esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 279.00, up 16.4 (+6.25%), High: 281.70, Low: 272.60, Volume: 817.49k
BE11:31am

Sunday Times does that story about Sir Peter Wood wanting to sell his 31%.

BE11:32am

You remember the one. We did it here, in July: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-07-10/

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:32am

And in terms of what's moved on .... not a lot, by the looks of things.

BE11:32am

The rumour back then was that Deutsche Bank has been sounding out potential buyers, starting with Direct Line and Hastings.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Who would appear to have run the numbers then backed out.

BE11:33am

Most likely for the reasons we discussed in that link above: cycle timing, relative valuations and all that stuff.

BE11:33am

(Hastings also had the AA thing going on, of course, though we didn't know that at the time.)

11:33 am
BE11:33am

So as the Sunday Times says, we're looking at the US, or China, or possibly PE.

BE11:33am

And there's no reason right now to assume we're looking at a bid for the whole.

BE11:33am

It might well be that Sir Peter sells 29.9%. It's his exit, he can do it how he likes.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

(@Soundbuy: I'm sure Tosca would like someone to pay 30-40% more for the shares than the market value. There are no guarantees that such a buyer exists, however, and Sir Peter might be happy just to crystalise the billion or so he's sitting on.)

undefined
PM11:36am

Ryanair mentioned on the right earlier

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Cancelling all these flights

PM11:36am

It seems a real muddl

PM11:36am

e

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Strikes and, erm, the weather

PM11:36am

And EU regulations

PM11:36am

What's going on??

11:36 am
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 16.70, down 0.44 (-2.57%), High: 16.92, Low: 16.36, Volume: 3.16m
BE11:37am

This is post the EU ruling last week, I think, that caused no little confusion.

BE11:37am

Which adds to a good old operational snafu.

11:37 am
PM11:38am

Ah, on labour rights

PM11:38am

ECJ ruling

BE11:38am

(@Tom Dalgleish: from your tone I guess you're needling us about something, but I can't work out what. Could you be clearer?)

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Let me get RBC, which has the neatest of the summaries.

BE11:39am

News reports (Guardian 15/9/17), BBC (17/9/7) suggest that Ryanair is exiting peak summer season with an operating timetable it is unable to staff to run fully. The company's own release (15/9/17) cites ATC issues, ATC strikes and other factors (crew holiday demands) as causing it to preemptively cancel around 2% of flights for 6 weeks to restore punctuality.
• However, in our view European summer ATC issues and strikes
(especially in France) are predictable - having caught out both easyJet and Vueling (in the last case, badly) in 2016.

BE11:39am

In our view, the company's reasons for its actions, while seeking
to restore punctuality, sound like 'football manager excuses'. Sitting outside the company these seem like compounding issues to a lack of staff planning - that risks over-trading when there was little slack in its system for the unpredictable, or per BBC reports (17/9/17) loss of flight deck crew to other LCCs like Norwegian.

11:39 am
PM11:40am

football manager excuses'

PM11:40am

hmm

BE11:40am

Company sees 2% of flights cancelled for 6 weeks - and alone we think this has a direct 1-3% risk to FY profits (on first thoughts). However, we see likely additional EU261 claim costs (so far unknown) when cancellations have been made at short notice. With 97% load factors we have yet to see a robust explanation of how affected customers will be accommodated.
• We see reputation damage beyond the direct cost. The poor PR could deter future bookings and may well put off more time sensitive higher yielding demand (like business trips) if the carrier is seen as unreliable and less punctual.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

• History has not been kind to LCCs that cannot deliver - for example we still find that Vuelling (part of IAG) retains its low skytrax ratings - and we believe it has to discount hardest where it faces competition in order to sell its product, based on our channel checks.
• Overall, it is the potential for long-term damage that concerns us. If Ryanair recovers the situation quickly and ensures its cancelled
customers are compensated and rebooked - on other airlines if need be - then we think that despite short-term cost the issue will pass. If not, and the situation worsens, or elongates, or Ryanair fails to do the 'right thing' and it receives further bad press then we see a possibility it could put at risk all the AGB efforts it has made. For now, we make no outlook revisions, but if the follow-on was to be mishandled we would then see downside risk to long-term forecasts and rating (potentially straight to U/P).

PM11:41am

(Tom D -- surely size is important. Footsie stocks tend to be far more liquid and better researched than smaller stuff. PFG nevertheless eye-catching.)

BE11:42am

We should also briefly recap the Mons case ..... Which has seen some confused reporting and some furious clarifications from the Ryanair spinners in recent days.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

This is the ECJ thing

BE11:42am

Yep. So ....... European Court of Justice ruled that Ryanair employees have the right to bring proceedings before courts located where they perform their duties rather than solely in
Ireland

BE11:43am

Most Ryanair employees live under Irish contracts ex-UK

11:43 am
BE11:43am

This might mean the whole Ryanair operating model unravels.

BE11:43am

Or it might not.

BE11:44am

HSBC had a downgrade last week on the back of the ECJ ruling that it had to correct.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Along the lines of, "all our working was wrong but we're still reaching the same conclusion".

BE11:45am

Certain details on the ECJ court ruling were not accurately represented in yesterday’s note, Ryanair: Downgrade to Reduce: Labour model in question. Our view of the company’s equity case, estimates and rating are however unchanged. For clarity, yesterday’s ECJ judgement did not rule against Ryanair’s use of Irish labour contracts for staff across the EU. It did not explicitly rule that crew’s place of work, which defines where disputes should be heard, is the same as the home base, but said the concept of home base is likely to play a significant role in identifying the place of work.

BE11:45am

Ryanair’s claim of a court victory looks unusual to us: However, the ECJ ruling did rule explicitly against Ryanair’s practice of imposing the Irish jurisdiction of labour contracts for all staff. The ruling also explicitly rejects Ryanair’s long-standing arguments that flight crew’s place of work is Ireland because they work on Irish registered aircraft or because they work for an airline with an Irish Air Operators Certificate. We expect both factors to encourage challenges to Ryanair employment practices, placing the use of Irish contracts under intense scrutiny.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

They're in the "beginning of the end" camp.

BE11:46am

Yesterday’s ruling is not the end of Ryanair’s employment structures, but does look to us like the beginning of the end. Given the building focus on the employment and tax practices of multi-national employers in Europe, and the building scrutiny on the use of zero hours contracts, we expect a flow of court challenges to Ryanair employment practices. We would expect these, after legal disputes, be heard in local courts. We expect this process will see Ryanair evolve, certainly reluctantly, to match peer practices of employing cockpit and cabin crew in the countries in which they are based.

BE11:46am

Credit Suisse is calmer.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Comfortable on court ruling but competition for pilots may be
intensifying: RYA confirmed the “Mons” ruling would not alter its Irish contracts or its labour costs. We also note the EC’s 2012 social security update (EC 883/2004, 987/2009) means RYA already pays national insurance in each employee’s base country. However, potentially coincidental, but RYA flight cancellations come following Norwegian Head of Communications Holmbergh Jacobsson highlighting to Svenska Dagbladet that Norwegian has “hired almost 140 RYA pilots so far this year”, reportedly equating to about a third of its hires, while RYA has introduced a one-off bonus of €10K for direct entry 737 qualified Captains as it prepares for 50 aircraft delivering in summer 2018. 2017A staff costs represented 9.5% of RYA revenue – we model RYA avoiding labour inflation and highlight each 1% of inflation would be worth €6.5m or 0.4% to net income from FY19E.

BE11:48am

And SocGen .........

BE11:48am

11:48 am
undefined
PM11:49am

Quick trip to the weeds.

PM11:49am

Well this is an example of self-weeding

11:49 am
PM11:49am

MySquar -- i company ive mentioned a couple of times

PM11:49am

Not to buy, just to watch

PM11:50am

Myanmar-language social media

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Obv not helped so much by recent newsflow from the country itself

PM11:50am

But how about this...

PM11:50am

MySQUAR, the Myanmar-language social media, entertainment and payments platform whose principal activity is to design, develop and commercialise Myanmar-focused internet-based mobile applications is pleased to announce that Eric Schaer, Chief Executive Officer of MySQUAR, is to give a presentation and join a panel discussion on technology, payments and cryptocurrency in London on Wednesday, 11th October 2017.

The event, which has been arranged by London South East (LSE), a leading private investor financial website, will be held between 6pm and 8pm at NEX Exchange, at 2 Broadgate, London EC2M 7UR.

11:50 am
PM11:50am

What sort of listed company voluntarily turns themselves into a muppet stock?

PM11:51am

Omg smileOmg smileOmg smile

BE11:51am

....................................... hm.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

That's madness. Or desperation

Mysquare Ltd (MYSQ:LSE): Last: 3.41, down 0.02 (-0.58%), High: 3.41, Low: 3.41, Volume: 1.27m
PM11:51am

And not working as yet

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Mysquare seems to come up in conversation more than you'd expect, for a Myanmar-language social media site.

BE11:52am

I've never quite understood why. Well, I have. But ..... actually, let's leave that there.

PM11:53am

It's not on the Hot chats board yet

11:53 am
PM11:53am

But maybe soon enough

BE11:53am

Omg smile

PM11:53am

11:53 am
undefined
BE11:54am

................ hm. That's quite a list.

BE11:54am

Anyway.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

On the insurance front there's this Deutsche upgrade of Admiral

BE11:55am

Oh? Go on.

PM11:55am

Ogden rate stuff

11:55 am
PM11:55am

The UK motor insurance has undergone yet another shift in its dynamic with
the proposed revision of the personal injury discount rate from a negative
0.75% to somewhere between 0%-1%. In our coverage both Direct Line and
Admiral are the clear beneficiaries with one-off reserve releases likely either in
2017 or 1H18 along with better competitive dynamics. In this note we update
our numbers to reflect this change, answer why motor insurance pricing is
likely to hold steady from here, and upgrade our rating on Admiral from Sell to
Hold. Finally, we also provide a detailed analysis of Admiral’s UK car business.

PM11:55am

Sorry for the formatting

PM11:55am

Ministry of Justice is proposing a new discount rate of between 0% to 1%
The MoJ announced on 7th September that the Lord Chancellor will present
draft legislation to change the methodology used to calculate the Ogden rate.
Their calculation suggests a rate between 0%-1% from -0.75% currently. They
have now invited comments on the this and intends to “legislate promptly”.

11:55 am
PM11:55am

YTD price increases have just kept pace with the increase in claims cost
Following this announcement, we modify our previous analysis which showed
the level of price increases required to offset the impact of lower Ogden rate
and attritional claims inflation on the new business. Our analysis on pp. 2-3
implies a 5-7% increase in prices is required to maintain current margins for a
0.5% Ogden rate (compared with 8-10% estimate for a -0.75% rate). With YTD
prices (adjusted for the IPT) having increased by c.6% we don’t see an
immediate risk of material price deflation. But equally there is limited prospect
for further margin improvement from here, prompting us to reduce our FY18-
19 EPS estimates on average by c.2% for Direct Line and c.3% for esure.
